message.content:
Verb tenses indicate when an action occurred. There are three main types of verb tenses: past, present, and future. Each type has four forms: simple, progressive (also called continuous), perfect, and perfect progressive (also called perfect continuous). Here's a breakdown of each tense:

1. Past Tense:
   - Simple: The action happened at a specific time in the past. Example: I ate breakfast.
   - Progressive: The action was ongoing at a specific time in the past. Example: I was eating breakfast.
   - Perfect: The action was completed before another event in the past. Example: I had eaten breakfast when my friend called.
   - Perfect Progressive: The action was ongoing and completed before another event in the past. Example: I had been eating breakfast when my friend called.

2. Present Tense:
   - Simple: The action is happening now or is a general fact. Example: I eat breakfast every morning.
   - Progressive: The action is ongoing at the moment. Example: I am eating breakfast right now.
   - Perfect: The action was completed before another event in the present. Example: I have eaten breakfast already.
   - Perfect Progressive: The action was ongoing and completed before another event in the present. Example: I have been eating breakfast since 7 am.

3. Future Tense:
   - Simple: The action will happen at a specific time in the future. Example: I will eat breakfast tomorrow morning.
   - Progressive: The action will be ongoing at a specific time in the future. Example: I will be eating breakfast when my friend arrives.
   - Perfect: The action will be completed before another event in the future. Example: I will have eaten breakfast by the time my friend arrives.
   - Perfect Progressive: The action will be ongoing and completed before another event in the future. Example: I will have been eating breakfast for an hour when my friend arrives.
